Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Laser-Matter Interactions on Atomic and Nanoscales
Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports the renewal of the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site in Physics at Kansas State University. The REU site will focus on interactions of laser light with matter at atomic and nanoscales. Each year the ten-week program will involve twelve undergraduate students. The participants will engage in significant research projects and related experiences during the summer. Participants will do research on how atoms and molecules behave in intense and ultra-fast optical and xray pulses, how scattered laser light reveals the structure of nanoparticle crystallization and gel formation, what eye-tracking reveals about how students learn, or how light interacts non-linearly in optical fibers; or they will develop computer codes for calculations of atomic interactions in Bose-Einstein condensates, for modeling nanoparticle self-assembly from lattices to gels, or for particle tracking for neutrino detection. This experience will be supplemented by a small series of lectures that provide the background these students need to carry out their projects. The participants will gain experience in explaining their research work to a variety of audiences and will also engage in reading on and discussion of ethical behavior in science. Social activities, both organized and spontaneous, will enrich this undergraduate research experience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Twelve students from around the United States were funded by the National Science Foundation to do research in physics at Kansas State University each summer from 2012-2014. These students were mostly from smaller colleges that offer fewer opportunities for research than we have available at KSU. For many of them this research experience confirmed their choice of a career in physics, but also helped some of them decide to pursue interests in engineering, medicine, or a non-technical area. It is good for our country that bright students make an informed career choice early in their education, and this NSF program, Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU), has advanced that national interest. They have sometimes done independent research, mentored by a KSU professor, but usually joined existing research groups that are already involved in basic research. The research they did ranged from computer simulations of how crystals evaporate to experimental work on how lasers can be used to manipulate the way molecules break up into their constituent atoms. Here are a few examples of the projects and the outcomes.

In 2012 one student joined an AMO (atomic, molecular, and optical physics) group and designed a device to compress part of a beam of ions into a small bunch. This makes the ion density greater, which is important for laser-atom interaction experiments. It also makes higher resolution possible in time-of-flight measurements. During the summer she ran simulations, altered her design, ran new simulations, and in the last week ordered the parts to make the actual device. Interestingly, another AMO student worked on a device for use as an alternative to time-of-flight measurements: a “velocity-map-imager”. This is one example of the useful “cross-talk” that occurs in our fairly tight-knit experimental community.

Condensed matter (CM) research is always popular in our program and in 2013 one student studied to what extent gold nanoparticles (the particles were roughly 10 nm in diameter) go into and out of solution. The particles were gold spheres coated with an organic molecule to prevent their clumping together into a lump of gold; the solvent was an organic liquid. He learned that the procedure he used showed some hysteresis, probably because he did not allow enough time for the solution to come to equilibrium. The next summer another student modified that procedure and she was able to determine the enthalpy of solution as a function of temperature. This research shows how to study the effects of particle size, organic coating, and solvent on the solubility of nanoparticles.

Even when a project does not result in scientific advancement, it has been a very valuable experience for the student involved. For example, one REU student spent the summer of 2014 writing the computer code to implement a new way to analyze neutrino oscillation data when the neutrino sources (nuclear reactors) are at many different distances from the detector. She succeeded in that but the new method was less effective than the existing one. In 2013 an AMO student calculated how the interaction of a laser with a CO molecule affected the way the molecule dissociated. The calculation disagreed with experiment, showing that the approximations used in the calculation were inadequate. Nevertheless, the excitement of comparing their work with real data confirmed the desire of both these students to do research in physics as a career. This NSF-sponsored REU program worked very well!
